an4.184:1.1.pli: Atha kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.184:1.1.eng: Then the brahmin Jānussoṇi went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.184:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.184:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an4.184:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, this is my doctrine and view:

an4.184:2.2.pli: ‘natthi yo maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassā’”ti.
an4.184:2.2.eng: ‘All those liable to death are frightened and terrified of death.’”

an4.184:2.3.pli: “Atthi, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa;
an4.184:2.3.eng: “Brahmin, some of those liable to death are frightened and terrified of death.

an4.184:2.4.pli: atthi pana, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:2.4.eng: But some of those liable to death are not frightened and terrified of death.

an4.184:3.1.pli: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa?
an4.184:3.1.eng: Who are those frightened of death?

an4.184:3.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco kāmesu avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
an4.184:3.2.eng: It’s someone who isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

an4.184:3.4.pli: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṃ hoti:

an4.184:3.5.pli: ‘piyā vata maṃ kāmā jahissanti, piye cāhaṃ kāme jahissāmī’ti.
an4.184:3.5.eng: ‘The sensual pleasures that I love so much will leave me, and I’ll leave them.’

an4.184:3.6.pli: So socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.184:3.6.eng: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.184:3.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:3.7.eng: This is someone who is frightened of death.

an4.184:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco kāye avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
an4.184:4.1.eng: Furthermore, it’s someone who isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for the body.

an4.184:4.3.pli: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṃ hoti:

an4.184:4.4.pli: ‘piyo vata maṃ kāyo jahissati, piyañcāhaṃ kāyaṃ jahissāmī’ti.
an4.184:4.4.eng: ‘This body that I love so much will leave me, and I’ll leave it.’

an4.184:4.5.pli: So socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.184:4.5.eng: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.184:4.6.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:4.6.eng: This, too, is someone who is frightened of death.

an4.184:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco akatakalyāṇo hoti akatakusalo akatabhīruttāṇo katapāpo kataluddo katakibbiso.
an4.184:5.1.eng: Furthermore, it’s someone who hasn’t done good and skillful things that keep them safe, but has done bad things, violence and sin.

an4.184:5.3.pli: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṃ hoti:

an4.184:5.4.pli: ‘akataṃ vata me kalyāṇaṃ, akataṃ kusalaṃ, akataṃ bhīruttāṇaṃ;
an4.184:5.4.eng: ‘Well, I haven’t done good and skillful things that keep me safe.

an4.184:5.5.pli: kataṃ pāpaṃ, kataṃ luddaṃ, kataṃ kibbisaṃ.
an4.184:5.5.eng: And I have done bad things, violence and sin.

an4.184:5.6.pli: Yāvatā, bho, akatakalyāṇānaṃ akatakusalānaṃ akatabhīruttāṇānaṃ katapāpānaṃ kataluddānaṃ katakibbisānaṃ gati taṃ gatiṃ pecca gacchāmī’ti.
an4.184:5.6.eng: When I depart, I’ll go to the place where people who’ve done such things go.’

an4.184:5.7.pli: So socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.184:5.7.eng: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.184:5.8.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:5.8.eng: This, too, is someone who is frightened of death.

an4.184:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco kaṅkhī hoti vicikicchī aniṭṭhaṅgato saddhamme.
an4.184:6.1.eng: Furthermore, it’s someone who’s doubtful, uncertain, and undecided about the true teaching.

an4.184:6.3.pli: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṃ hoti:

an4.184:6.4.eng: ‘I’m doubtful, uncertain, and undecided about the true teaching.’

an4.184:6.5.pli: So socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.184:6.5.eng: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.184:6.6.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno bhāyati, santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:6.6.eng: This, too, is someone who is frightened of death.

an4.184:6.7.pli: Ime kho, brāhmaṇa, cattāro maraṇadhammā samānā bhāyanti, santāsaṃ āpajjanti maraṇassa.
an4.184:6.7.eng: These are the four individuals liable to death who are frightened and terrified of death.

an4.184:7.1.pli: Katamo ca, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa?
an4.184:7.1.eng: Who are those not frightened of death?

an4.184:7.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco kāmesu vītarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho.
an4.184:7.2.eng: It’s someone who is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

an4.184:7.4.pli: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa na evaṃ hoti:

an4.184:7.5.pli: ‘piyā vata maṃ kāmā jahissanti, piye cāhaṃ kāme jahissāmī’ti.
an4.184:7.5.eng: ‘The sensual pleasures that I love so much will leave me, and I’ll leave them.’

an4.184:7.6.pli: So na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.184:7.6.eng: They don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.184:7.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:7.7.eng: This is someone who’s not frightened of death.

an4.184:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco kāye vītarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho.
an4.184:8.1.eng: Furthermore, it’s someone who is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for the body.

an4.184:8.3.pli: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa na evaṃ hoti:

an4.184:8.4.pli: ‘piyo vata maṃ kāyo jahissati, piyañcāhaṃ kāyaṃ jahissāmī’ti.
an4.184:8.4.eng: ‘This body that I love so much will leave me, and I’ll leave it.’

an4.184:8.5.pli: So na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.184:8.5.eng: They don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.184:8.6.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:8.6.eng: This, too, is someone who’s not frightened of death.

an4.184:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco akatapāpo hoti akataluddo akatakibbiso katakalyāṇo katakusalo katabhīruttāṇo.
an4.184:9.1.eng: Furthermore, it’s someone who hasn’t done bad things, violence and sin, but has done good and skillful deeds that keep them safe.

an4.184:9.3.pli: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṃ hoti:

an4.184:9.4.pli: ‘akataṃ vata me pāpaṃ, akataṃ luddaṃ, akataṃ kibbisaṃ;
an4.184:9.4.eng: ‘Well, I haven’t done bad things, violence and sin.

an4.184:9.5.pli: kataṃ kalyāṇaṃ, kataṃ kusalaṃ, kataṃ bhīruttāṇaṃ.
an4.184:9.5.eng: And I have done good and skillful deeds that keep me safe.

an4.184:9.6.pli: Yāvatā, bho, akatapāpānaṃ akataluddānaṃ akatakibbisānaṃ katakalyāṇānaṃ katakusalānaṃ katabhīruttāṇānaṃ gati taṃ gatiṃ pecca gacchāmī’ti.
an4.184:9.6.eng: When I depart, I’ll go to the place where people who’ve done such things go.’

an4.184:9.7.pli: So na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.184:9.7.eng: They don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.184:9.8.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:9.8.eng: This, too, is someone who’s not frightened of death.

an4.184:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, idhekacco akaṅkhī hoti avicikicchī niṭṭhaṅgato saddhamme.
an4.184:10.1.eng: Furthermore, it’s someone who’s not doubtful, uncertain, or undecided about the true teaching.

an4.184:10.3.pli: Tassa aññatarena gāḷhena rogātaṅkena phuṭṭhassa evaṃ hoti:

an4.184:10.4.eng: ‘I’m not doubtful, uncertain, or undecided about the true teaching.’

an4.184:10.5.pli: So na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an4.184:10.5.eng: They don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an4.184:10.6.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, maraṇadhammo samāno na bhāyati, na santāsaṃ āpajjati maraṇassa.
an4.184:10.6.eng: This, too, is someone who’s not frightened of death.

an4.184:10.7.pli: Ime kho, brāhmaṇa, cattāro maraṇadhammā samānā na bhāyanti, na santāsaṃ āpajjanti maraṇassā”ti.
an4.184:10.7.eng: These are the four individuals liable to death who are not frightened and terrified of death.”

an4.184:11.1.pli: “Abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama …pe… upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an4.184:11.1.eng: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! … From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

an4.185:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
an4.185:1.1.eng: Once the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

an4.185:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā paribbājakā sippinikātīre paribbājakārāme paṭivasanti, seyyathidaṃ annabhāro varadharo sakuludāyī ca paribbājako aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā paribbājakā.
an4.185:1.2.eng: Now at that time several very well-known wanderers were residing in the monastery of the wanderers on the bank of the Serpentine river. They included Annabhāra, Varadhara, Sakuludāyī, and other very well-known wanderers.

an4.185:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena sippinikātīre paribbājakārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
an4.185:1.3.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the wanderer’s monastery on the bank of the Serpentine river.

an4.185:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarā kathā udapādi:
an4.185:2.1.eng: Now at that time this discussion came up while those wanderers of other religions were sitting together,

an4.185:2.2.eng: “The truths of the brahmins are like this; the truths of the brahmins are like that.”

an4.185:2.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena te paribbājakā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā te paribbājake etadavoca:
an4.185:2.3.eng: Then the Buddha went up to those wanderers, sat down on the seat spread out, and said to them,

an4.185:3.1.pli: “Kāya nuttha, paribbājakā, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
an4.185:3.1.eng: “Wanderers, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”

an4.185:3.2.pli: “Idha, bho gotama, amhākaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
an4.185:3.2.eng: “Well, worthy Gotama, this discussion came up among us while we were sitting together:

an4.185:3.3.eng: ‘The truths of the brahmins are like this; the truths of the brahmins are like that.’”

an4.185:4.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, paribbājakā, brāhmaṇasaccāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an4.185:4.1.eng: “Wanderers, I declare these four truths of the brahmins, having realized them with my own insight.

an4.185:4.5.pli: Iti vadaṃ brāhmaṇo saccaṃ āha, no musā.
an4.185:4.5.eng: In speaking like this, a brahmin speaks the truth, not lies.

an4.185:4.6.pli: So tena na samaṇoti maññati, na brāhmaṇoti maññati, na seyyohamasmīti maññati, na sadisohamasmīti maññati, na hīnohamasmīti maññati.
an4.185:4.6.eng: But they don’t think of themselves as an ‘ascetic’ or ‘brahmin’ because of that. Nor do they think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.

an4.185:4.7.pli: Api ca yadeva tattha saccaṃ tadabhiññāya pāṇānaṃyeva anuddayāya anukampāya paṭipanno hoti.
an4.185:4.7.eng: Rather, they simply practice out of kindness and sympathy for living creatures, having had insight into the truth of that.

an4.185:5.2.eng: ‘All sensual pleasures are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’

an4.185:5.3.pli: Iti vadaṃ brāhmaṇo saccamāha, no musā.
an4.185:5.3.eng: Saying this, a brahmin speaks the truth, not lies.

an4.185:5.4.pli: So tena na samaṇoti maññati, na brāhmaṇoti maññati, na seyyohamasmīti maññati, na sadisohamasmīti maññati, na hīnohamasmīti maññati.
an4.185:5.4.eng: But they don’t think of themselves as an ‘ascetic’ or ‘brahmin’ because of that. Nor do they think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.

an4.185:5.5.pli: Api ca yadeva tattha saccaṃ tadabhiññāya kāmānaṃyeva nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
an4.185:5.5.eng: Rather, they simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding sensual pleasures, having had insight into the truth of that.

an4.185:6.2.pli: ‘sabbe bhavā aniccā …pe… tadabhiññāya bhavānaṃyeva nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
an4.185:6.2.eng: ‘All states of existence are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ … They simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding future lives, having had insight into the truth of that.

an4.185:7.2.pli: ‘nāhaṃ kvacani kassaci kiñcanatasmiṃ na ca mama kvacani katthaci kiñcanatatthī’ti.
an4.185:7.2.eng: ‘I don’t belong to anyone anywhere. And nothing belongs to me anywhere.’

an4.185:7.3.pli: Iti vadaṃ brāhmaṇo saccaṃ āha, no musā.
an4.185:7.3.eng: In speaking like this, a brahmin speaks the truth, not lies.

an4.185:7.4.pli: So tena na samaṇoti maññati, na brāhmaṇoti maññati, na seyyohamasmīti maññati, na sadisohamasmīti maññati, na hīnohamasmīti maññati.
an4.185:7.4.eng: But they don’t think of themselves as an ‘ascetic’ or ‘brahmin’ because of that. Nor do they think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.

an4.185:7.5.pli: Api ca yadeva tattha saccaṃ tadabhiññāya ākiñcaññaṃyeva paṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti.
an4.185:7.5.eng: Rather, they simply practice the path of nothingness, having had insight into the truth of that.

an4.185:7.6.pli: Imāni kho, paribbājakā, cattāri brāhmaṇasaccāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
an4.185:7.6.eng: These are the four truths of the brahmins that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

an4.186:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.186:1.1.eng: Then one of the mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an4.186:1.2.pli: “kena nu kho, bhante, loko nīyati, kena loko parikassati, kassa ca uppannassa vasaṃ gacchatī”ti?
an4.186:1.2.eng: “Sir, what leads the world on? What drags it around? What arises and takes control?”

an4.186:2.2.pli: Bhaddako kho te, bhikkhu, ummaggo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
an4.186:2.2.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.

an4.186:2.4.pli: ‘kena nu kho, bhante, loko nīyati, kena loko parikassati, kassa ca uppannassa vasaṃ gacchatī’”ti?
an4.186:2.4.eng: ‘What leads the world on? What drags it around? What arises and takes control?’”

an4.186:2.6.pli: “Cittena kho, bhikkhu, loko nīyati, cittena parikassati, cittassa uppannassa vasaṃ gacchatī”ti.
an4.186:2.6.eng: “Mendicant, the mind leads the world on. The mind drags it around. When the mind arises, it takes control.”

an4.186:3.1.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ uttari pañhaṃ apucchi:
an4.186:3.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:

an4.186:3.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘a learned memorizer of the teaching’.

an4.186:3.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bahussuto dhammadharo hotī”ti?
an4.186:3.3.eng: How is a learned memorizer of the teaching defined?”

an4.186:4.2.pli: Bhaddako kho te, bhikkhu ummaggo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
an4.186:4.2.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question. …

an4.186:4.5.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bahussuto dhammadharo hotī’”ti?

an4.186:4.8.pli: suttaṃ, geyyaṃ, veyyākaraṇaṃ, gāthā, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, jātakaṃ, abbhutadhammaṃ, vedallaṃ.
an4.186:4.8.eng: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.

an4.186:4.9.pli: Catuppadāya cepi, bhikkhu, gāthāya atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno hoti bahussuto dhammadharoti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
an4.186:4.9.eng: But if anyone understands the meaning and the text of even a four-line verse, and if they practice in line with that teaching, they’re qualified to be called a ‘learned memorizer of the teaching’.”

an4.186:5.1.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ uttari pañhaṃ apucchi:
an4.186:5.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:

an4.186:5.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘a learned person with penetrating wisdom’.

an4.186:5.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, sutavā nibbedhikapañño hotī”ti?
an4.186:5.3.eng: How is a learned person with penetrating wisdom defined?”

an4.186:6.2.pli: Bhaddako kho te, bhikkhu, ummaggo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
an4.186:6.2.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question. …

an4.186:6.5.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, sutavā nibbedhikapañño hotī’”ti?

an4.186:6.7.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, bhikkhuno ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti sutaṃ hoti, paññāya cassa atthaṃ ativijjha passati;
an4.186:6.7.eng: Take a mendicant who has heard: ‘This is suffering.’ They see what it means with penetrating wisdom.

an4.186:6.8.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti sutaṃ hoti, paññāya cassa atthaṃ ativijjha passati;
an4.186:6.8.eng: They’ve heard: ‘This is the origin of suffering’ …

an4.186:6.9.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti sutaṃ hoti, paññāya cassa atthaṃ ativijjha passati;

an4.186:6.10.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti sutaṃ hoti, paññāya cassa atthaṃ ativijjha passati.
an4.186:6.10.eng: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ They see what it means with penetrating wisdom.

an4.186:6.11.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sutavā nibbedhikapañño hotī”ti.
an4.186:6.11.eng: That’s how an individual is learned, with penetrating wisdom.”

an4.186:7.1.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ uttari pañhaṃ apucchi:
an4.186:7.1.eng: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:

an4.186:7.2.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘an astute person with great wisdom’.

an4.186:7.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, paṇḍito mahāpañño hotī”ti?
an4.186:7.3.eng: How is an astute person with great wisdom defined?”

an4.186:8.2.pli: Bhaddako kho te, bhikkhu, ummaggo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
an4.186:8.2.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question. …

an4.186:8.5.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, paṇḍito mahāpañño hotī’”ti?

an4.186:8.7.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, paṇḍito mahāpañño nevattabyābādhāya ceteti na parabyābādhāya ceteti na ubhayabyābādhāya ceteti attahitaparahitaubhayahitasabbalokahitameva cintayamāno cinteti.
an4.186:8.7.eng: An astute person with great wisdom is one who has no intention to hurt themselves, or to hurt others, or to hurt both. When they think, they only think of the benefit for themselves, for others, for both, and for the whole world.

an4.186:8.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, paṇḍito mahāpañño hotī”ti.
an4.186:8.8.eng: That’s how an individual is astute, with great wisdom.”

an4.187:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
an4.187:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

an4.187:1.2.pli: Atha kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.187:1.2.eng: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, a chief minister of Magadha, went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.187:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.187:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an4.187:2.1.pli: “Jāneyya nu kho, bho gotama, asappuriso asappurisaṃ:
an4.187:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, could an untrue person know of an untrue person:

an4.187:2.2.eng: ‘This worthy one is an untrue person’?”

an4.187:2.3.pli: “Aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, anavakāso yaṃ asappuriso asappurisaṃ jāneyya:

an4.187:2.5.eng: “Could an untrue person know of a true person:

an4.187:2.6.eng: ‘This worthy one is a true person’?”

an4.187:2.7.pli: “Etampi kho, brāhmaṇa, aṭṭhānaṃ anavakāso yaṃ asappuriso sappurisaṃ jāneyya:
an4.187:2.7.eng: “That too is impossible, it can’t happen.”

an4.187:2.9.pli: “Jāneyya nu kho, bho gotama, sappuriso sappurisaṃ:
an4.187:2.9.eng: “Worthy Gotama, could a true person know of a true person:

an4.187:2.10.eng: ‘This worthy one is a true person’?”

an4.187:2.11.pli: “Ṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, vijjati yaṃ sappuriso sappurisaṃ jāneyya:

an4.187:2.13.eng: “Could a true person know of an untrue person:

an4.187:2.14.eng: ‘This worthy one is an untrue person’?”

an4.187:2.15.pli: “Etampi kho, brāhmaṇa, ṭhānaṃ vijjati yaṃ sappuriso asappurisaṃ jāneyya:

an4.187:3.2.eng: how well said this was by the worthy Gotama:

an4.187:3.3.pli: ‘aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, anavakāso yaṃ asappuriso asappurisaṃ jāneyya—
an4.187:3.3.eng: ‘It’s impossible, it can’t happen, that an untrue person could know …

an4.187:3.5.pli: Etampi kho, brāhmaṇa, aṭṭhānaṃ anavakāso yaṃ asappuriso sappurisaṃ jāneyya—

an4.187:3.7.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, vijjati yaṃ sappuriso sappurisaṃ jāneyya—
an4.187:3.7.eng: But it is possible that a true person could know …’

an4.187:3.9.pli: Etampi kho, brāhmaṇa, ṭhānaṃ vijjati yaṃ sappuriso asappurisaṃ jāneyya—

an4.187:4.1.pli: Ekamidaṃ, bho gotama, samayaṃ todeyyassa brāhmaṇassa parisati parūpārambhaṃ vattenti:
an4.187:4.1.eng: Once, members of the brahmin Todeyya’s assembly were going on complaining about others:

an4.187:4.2.pli: ‘bālo ayaṃ rājā eḷeyyo samaṇe rāmaputte abhippasanno, samaṇe ca pana rāmaputte evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karoti, yadidaṃ abhivādanaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ añjalikammaṃ sāmīcikammanti.
an4.187:4.2.eng: ‘This King Eḷeyya is a fool to be so devoted to the ascetic Rāmaputta. He even shows him the utmost deference by bowing down to him, rising up for him, greeting him with joined palms, and observing proper etiquette for him.

an4.187:4.3.eng: And these king’s men are fools too—

an4.187:4.4.pli: yamako moggallo uggo nāvindakī gandhabbo aggivesso, ye samaṇe rāmaputte abhippasannā, samaṇe ca pana rāmaputte evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karonti, yadidaṃ abhivādanaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ añjalikammaṃ sāmīcikamman’ti.
an4.187:4.4.eng: Yamaka, Moggalla, Ugga, Nāvindakī, Gandhabba, and Aggivessa—for they show the same kind of deference to Rāmaputta.’

an4.187:4.5.pli: Tyāssudaṃ todeyyo brāhmaṇo iminā nayena neti.
an4.187:4.5.eng: Then the brahmin Todeyya reasoned with them like this:

an4.187:4.7.pli: paṇḍito rājā eḷeyyo karaṇīyādhikaraṇīyesu vacanīyādhivacanīyesu alamatthadasatarehi alamatthadasataro’ti?
an4.187:4.7.eng: When it comes to the various duties and speeches, isn’t King Eḷeyya astute, even better than the experts?’

an4.187:4.8.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bho, paṇḍito rājā eḷeyyo karaṇīyādhikaraṇīyesu vacanīyādhivacanīyesu alamatthadasatarehi alamatthadasataroti.

an4.187:5.1.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bho, samaṇo rāmaputto raññā eḷeyyena paṇḍitena paṇḍitataro karaṇīyādhikaraṇīyesu vacanīyādhivacanīyesu alamatthadasatarena alamatthadasataro, tasmā rājā eḷeyyo samaṇe rāmaputte abhippasanno, samaṇe ca pana rāmaputte evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karoti, yadidaṃ abhivādanaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ añjalikammaṃ sāmīcikammaṃ’.
an4.187:5.1.eng: ‘It’s because the ascetic Rāmaputta is even more astute and expert than King Eḷeyya that the king is so devoted to him. That’s why he even shows Rāmaputta the utmost deference by bowing down to him, rising up for him, greeting him with joined palms, and observing proper etiquette for him.

an4.187:6.3.pli: yamako moggallo uggo nāvindakī gandhabbo aggivesso, karaṇīyādhikaraṇīyesu vacanīyādhivacanīyesu alamatthadasatarehi alamatthadasatarā’ti?
an4.187:6.3.eng: When it comes to the various duties and speeches, aren’t the king’s men—Yamaka, Moggalla, Ugga, Nāvindakī, Gandhabba, and Aggivessa—astute, even better than the experts?’

an4.187:6.5.pli: yamako moggallo uggo nāvindakī gandhabbo aggivesso, karaṇīyādhikaraṇīyesu vacanīyādhivacanīyesu alamatthadasatarehi alamatthadasatarāti.

an4.187:7.1.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bho, samaṇo rāmaputto rañño eḷeyyassa parihārakehi paṇḍitehi paṇḍitataro karaṇīyādhikaraṇīyesu vacanīyādhivacanīyesu alamatthadasatarehi alamatthadasataro, tasmā rañño eḷeyyassa parihārakā samaṇe rāmaputte abhippasannā;
an4.187:7.1.eng: ‘It’s because Rāmaputta is even more astute and expert than the king’s men that they have such devotion to him. …

an4.187:7.2.pli: samaṇe ca pana rāmaputte evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karonti, yadidaṃ abhivādanaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ añjalikammaṃ sāmīcikamman’ti.
an4.187:7.2.eng: It’s because Rāmaputta is even more astute and expert than King Eḷeyya that the king is so devoted to him. That’s why he even shows Rāmaputta the utmost deference by bowing down to him, rising up for him, greeting him with joined palms, and observing proper etiquette for him.’

an4.187:8.1.pli: Acchariyaṃ, bho gotama, abbhutaṃ, bho gotama.
an4.187:8.1.eng: It’s incredible, worthy Gotama, it’s amazing,

an4.187:8.2.eng: how well said this was by the worthy Gotama:

an4.187:8.3.pli: ‘aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, anavakāso yaṃ asappuriso asappurisaṃ jāneyya—
an4.187:8.3.eng: ‘It’s impossible, it can’t happen, that an untrue person could know …

an4.187:8.5.pli: Etampi kho, brāhmaṇa, aṭṭhānaṃ anavakāso yaṃ asappuriso sappurisaṃ jāneyya—

an4.187:8.7.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, vijjati yaṃ sappuriso sappurisaṃ jāneyya—
an4.187:8.7.eng: But it is possible that a true person could know …

an4.187:8.9.pli: Etampi kho, brāhmaṇa, ṭhānaṃ vijjati yaṃ sappuriso asappurisaṃ jāneyya—

an4.187:8.11.pli: Handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bho gotama, gacchāma.
an4.187:8.11.eng: Well, now, worthy Gotama, I must go.

an4.187:8.12.eng: I have many duties, and much to do.”

an4.187:9.1.pli: Atha kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.
an4.187:9.1.eng: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat and left.

an4.188:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
an4.188:1.1.eng: Once the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

an4.188:1.2.pli: Atha kho upako maṇḍikāputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho upako maṇḍikāputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.188:1.2.eng: Then Upaka the son of Maṇḍikā went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an4.188:2.1.eng: “Sir, this is my doctrine and view:

an4.188:2.2.pli: ‘yo koci parūpārambhaṃ vatteti, parūpārambhaṃ vattento sabbo so na upapādeti.
an4.188:2.2.eng: ‘Whoever goes on complaining about others without giving any reasons

an4.188:2.4.pli: “Parūpārambhañce, upaka, vatteti parūpārambhaṃ vattento na upapādeti, anupapādento gārayho hoti upavajjo.
an4.188:2.4.eng: “Upaka, if someone goes on complaining about others without giving a reason, they’re reprehensible and at fault.

an4.188:2.5.pli: Tvaṃ kho, upaka, parūpārambhaṃ vattesi, parūpārambhaṃ vattento na upapādesi, anupapādento gārayho hosi upavajjo”ti.
an4.188:2.5.eng: But that’s what you do, so you’re reprehensible and at fault!”

an4.188:2.6.eng: “Sir, like a fish caught in a big trap just as it rises,

an4.188:2.7.pli: evamevaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, ummujjamānakoyeva bhagavatā mahatā vādapāsena baddho”ti.
an4.188:2.7.eng: so the Buddha caught me in a big trap of words just as I rose up.”

an4.188:3.2.pli: Tattha aparimāṇā padā aparimāṇā byañjanā aparimāṇā tathāgatassa dhammadesanā—
an4.188:3.2.eng: And there are limitless words, phrases, and teachings of the Realized One about that:

an4.188:3.3.eng: ‘This is another way of saying that this is unskillful.’

an4.188:3.4.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ akusalaṃ pahātabbanti kho, upaka, mayā paññattaṃ.
an4.188:3.4.eng: I’ve declared: ‘The unskillful should be given up.’

an4.188:3.5.pli: Tattha aparimāṇā padā aparimāṇā byañjanā aparimāṇā tathāgatassa dhammadesanā—
an4.188:3.5.eng: And there are limitless words, phrases, and teachings of the Realized One about that:

an4.188:3.6.eng: ‘This is another way of saying that the unskillful should be given up.’

an4.188:4.1.pli: Idaṃ kusalanti kho, upaka, mayā paññattaṃ.

an4.188:4.2.pli: Tattha aparimāṇā padā aparimāṇā byañjanā aparimāṇā tathāgatassa dhammadesanā—
an4.188:4.2.eng: And there are limitless words, phrases, and teachings of the Realized One about that:

an4.188:4.3.eng: ‘This is another way of saying that this is skillful.’

an4.188:4.4.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ kusalaṃ bhāvetabbanti kho, upaka, mayā paññattaṃ.
an4.188:4.4.eng: I’ve declared: ‘The skillful should be developed.’

an4.188:4.5.pli: Tattha aparimāṇā padā aparimāṇā byañjanā aparimāṇā tathāgatassa dhammadesanā—
an4.188:4.5.eng: And there are limitless words, phrases, and teachings of the Realized One about that:

an4.188:4.6.eng: ‘This is another way of saying that the skillful should be developed.’”

an4.188:5.1.pli: Atha kho upako maṇḍikāputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā yāvatako ahosi bhagavatā saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa ārocesi.
an4.188:5.1.eng: And then Upaka son of Maṇḍikā approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went up to King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha. He told the King of all they had discussed.

an4.188:5.2.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto kupito anattamano upakaṃ maṇḍikāputtaṃ etadavoca:
an4.188:5.2.eng: But Ajātasattu became angry and upset, and said to Upaka,

an4.188:5.3.pli: “yāva dhaṃsī vatāyaṃ loṇakāradārako yāva mukharo yāva pagabbo yatra hi nāma taṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ āsādetabbaṃ maññissati;
an4.188:5.3.eng: “How rude of this salt-maker’s boy! How scurrilous and impudent of him to imagine he could attack the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

an4.188:5.4.pli: apehi tvaṃ, upaka, vinassa, mā taṃ addasan”ti.
an4.188:5.4.eng: Get out, Upaka, go away! Don’t let me see you again.”

an4.189:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four things should be realized.

an4.189:1.3.eng: There are things to be realized with direct meditative experience.

an4.189:1.4.eng: There are things to be realized with recollection.

an4.189:1.5.eng: There are things to be realized with vision.

an4.189:1.6.eng: There are things to be realized with wisdom.

an4.189:1.7.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā kāyena sacchikaraṇīyā?
an4.189:1.7.eng: What things are to be realized with direct meditative experience?

an4.189:2.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā satiyā sacchikaraṇīyā?
an4.189:2.1.eng: What things are to be realized with recollection?

an4.189:3.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā cakkhunā sacchikaraṇīyā?
an4.189:3.1.eng: What things are to be realized with vision?

an4.189:3.2.eng: The passing away and rebirth of sentient beings.

an4.189:4.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, dhammā paññāya sacchikaraṇīyā?
an4.189:4.1.eng: What things are to be realized with wisdom?

an4.189:4.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro sacchikaraṇīyā dhammā”ti.
an4.189:4.3.eng: These are the four things to be realized.”
